runtime/src/thirdparty/nedmalloc/embedded_printf.h

00001 #if defined(_DEBUG) && defined(USE_DEBUGGER_OUTPUT)
00002 
00003 /*
00004 File: printf.h
00005 
00006 Copyright (C) 2004  Kustaa Nyholm
00007 
00008 This library is free software; you can redistribute it and/or
00009 modify it under the terms of the GNU Lesser General Public
00010 License as published by the Free Software Foundation; either
00011 version 2.1 of the License, or (at your option) any later version.
00012 
00013 This library is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
00014 but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
00015 MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  
00016 See the GNU Lesser General Public License for more details.
00017 
00018 You should have received a copy of the GNU Lesser General Public
00019 License along with this library; if not, write to the Free Software
00020 Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330, Boston, MA  02111-1307  USA
00021 
00022 This library is realy just two files: 'printf.h' and 'printf.c'.
00023 
00024 They provide a simple and small (+200 loc) printf functionality to 
00025 be used in embedded systems.
00026 
00027 I've found them so usefull in debugging that I do not bother with a 
00028 debugger at all.
00029 
00030 They are distributed in source form, so to use them, just compile them 
00031 into your project. 
00032 
00033 Two printf variants are provided: printf and sprintf. 
00034 
00035 The formats supported by this implementation are: 'd' 'u' 'c' 's' 'x' 'X'.
00036 
00037 Zero padding and field width are also supported.
00038 
00039 If the library is compiled with 'PRINTF_SUPPORT_LONG' defined then the 
00040 long specifier is also
00041 supported. Note that this will pull in some long math routines (pun intended!)
00042 and thus make your executable noticably longer.
00043 
00044 The memory foot print of course depends on the target cpu, compiler and 
00045 compiler options, but a rough guestimate (based on a H8S target) is about 
00046 1.4 kB for code and some twenty 'int's and 'char's, say 60 bytes of stack space. 
00047 Not too bad. Your milage may vary. By hacking the source code you can 
00048 get rid of some hunred bytes, I'm sure, but personally I feel the balance of 
00049 functionality and flexibility versus  code size is close to optimal for
00050 many embedded systems.
00051 
00052 To use the printf you need to supply your own character output function, 
00053 something like :
00054 
00055         void putc ( void* p, char c)
00056                 {
00057                 while (!SERIAL_PORT_EMPTY) ;
00058                 SERIAL_PORT_TX_REGISTER = c;
00059                 }
00060 
00061 Before you can call printf you need to initialize it to use your 
00062 character output function with something like:
00063 
00064         init_printf(NULL,putc);
00065 
00066 Notice the 'NULL' in 'init_printf' and the parameter 'void* p' in 'putc', 
00067 the NULL (or any pointer) you pass into the 'init_printf' will eventually be 
00068 passed to your 'putc' routine. This allows you to pass some storage space (or 
00069 anything realy) to the character output function, if necessary. 
00070 This is not often needed but it was implemented like that because it made 
00071 implementing the sprintf function so neat (look at the source code).
00072 
00073 The code is re-entrant, except for the 'init_printf' function, so it 
00074 is safe to call it from interupts too, although this may result in mixed output. 
00075 If you rely on re-entrancy, take care that your 'putc' function is re-entrant!
00076 
00077 The printf and sprintf functions are actually macros that translate to 
00078 'tfp_printf' and 'tfp_sprintf'. This makes it possible
00079 to use them along with 'stdio.h' printf's in a single source file. 
00080 You just need to undef the names before you include the 'stdio.h'.
00081 Note that these are not function like macros, so if you have variables
00082 or struct members with these names, things will explode in your face.
00083 Without variadic macros this is the best we can do to wrap these
00084 fucnction. If it is a problem just give up the macros and use the
00085 functions directly or rename them.
00086 
00087 For further details see source code.
00088 
00089 regs Kusti, 23.10.2004
00090 */
00091 
00092 
00093 #ifndef __TFP_PRINTF__
00094 #define __TFP_PRINTF__
00095 
00096 #include <stdarg.h>
00097 
00098 void init_printf(void* putp,void (*putf) (void*,char));
00099 
00100 void tfp_printf(const char *fmt, ...);
00101 void tfp_sprintf(char* s,const char *fmt, ...);
00102 
00103 void tfp_format(void* putp,void (*putf) (void*,char),const char *fmt, va_list va);
00104 /*
00105 #define printf tfp_printf 
00106 #define sprintf tfp_sprintf 
00107 */
00108 #endif
00109 
00110 #endif
